title: Can a debt agency take me to court for my student loan?
question: I owe 1200 in a student loan and have no way of paying it. I have received multiple calls from an attorneys office saying they were going to take legal action. What will happen? I am on public assistance and can barley support my daughter. What would be the best thing to do?
question_tags: Intellectual property,Patents,Bankruptcy,Debt,Debt settlement,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Bankruptcy and debt,State, local, and municipal law,Filing a lawsuit
answers: I suggest you start keeping a log of those phone calls. Get the name and phone number of the person(s) calling you and keep notes of what is said during the phone call. Under federal and state law it is illegal to harass (multiple phone calls) you while trying to collect a debt. If successful you can be awarded up to $1000.00, plus have your attorneys' fees paid for. I recommend you talk to a lawyer who specializes in debt collection issues and many will talk to you for free the first time. NACA.net is a great resource for finding a lawyer in your area.

Have they been made aware of your situation? It may quell their aggressive nature or it may cause them to choose to refrain from action. Do you tell them when they call? Have you provided any public assistance documents?

You may want to screen calls (those fancy modern phones do everything don't they?).

There can be litigation filed, even though it appears you do not have the ability to pay.
There may be some assistance available as to the student loan, thru a program being offered by the US Department of Education, to allow forgiveness, cancellation or discharge, under limited circumstances.
You can read about this at www.studentaid.ed.gov/repay-loans/forgiveness-cancellation.
It may be helpful to consult with an experienced local bankruptcy attorney.

They certainly can sue you for the debt that you owe, and they'll obtain a judgment against you as well. Whether or not they can COLLECT is a separate issue. Given your current financial situation, they probably cannot collect on the judgment. There really isn't anything for you to do - if you admit you owe it (which you do), and you can't pay it (which you can't), then you'll simply have to accept that they will continue to hound you. You cannot discharge it in bankruptcy, although if you have other debt issues, that may be something to consider. Sit down with a local bankruptcy attorney to discuss this.
